text: Procedural content generation has
received noteworthy enhancements in
Unreal Engine 5.6 and 5.7. In Unreal
Engine 5.7, PCG is now production ready.
With better GPUdriven performance, you
can create worlds and manage complex
scenes more efficiently than before.
This video covers important updates that
can improve your process, including
templates, new viewports, biome
advancements, and more. Let's start with
some of the updates within Unreal Engine
5.6, and then we'll take a look at
what's been added in Unreal Engine 5.7.
The first thing you will want to do when
exploring PCG tools is turn on the
procedural content generation framework
plugin by going to edit plugins and
searching for PCG.
Enable the plugin and restart your
project as needed. Now let's take a look
at some of the new features. Let's begin
with the node graph. Once you have the
PCG plug-in enabled, you can rightclick
in the content browser, go to PCG, and
select PCG graph. New to Unreal Engine
5.6 is this template window where you
can select a template graph as a
starting point with preconfigured nodes
and graph parameters. It is an easy way
to preconfigure graphs for users of a
system relying on PCG or provide
examples. Once you select your template
of choice, hit initialize. Now, let's
take a look at the updates within the
graph here. One of the bigger updates to
this window is the data viewport to
preview data of any inspected node,
helping you work in context with
iterative workflows for both world and
asset creation.
This means you can preview points,
textures, and meshes directly in this
viewport while editing. Additionally,
there is now a dedicated graph
parameters panel that can be docked
anywhere in the PCG graph editor. You
now have easier access to create new
constants or parameters by
right-clicking and selecting graph
parameters from the node pallet. After
creating your graph parameters, you have
the ability to organize them by
reordering parameters. Simply drag them
to the desired location. Further
organized by categorizing the parameters
to keep your work clean and orderly. The
node graph has also been updated to
support inline constant, making it
easier for you to create, drag and drop,
and manipulate elements. You have the
ability to enter constant values
directly on the node input pins without
having to create a separate constant
node. Now, let's move on to creating and
editing biomes, which is now faster and
more intuitive with the PCG Biome Core
V2 plugin. To explore this update, you
can enable two plugins by going to edit,
plugins, enable PCG Biome Core and PCG
Biome Sample, then restart your project.
These plugins have received a big
overhaul of the PCGbased tool to address
performance, improve workflows, and add
new features such as per biome blending.
Per biome blending gives you control
over blending range, noise, and density.
Additionally, you have support for
layering multiple biomes instead of the
previous binary behavior, giving you
greater control to build rich organic
environments more efficiently.
In general, these features are efficient
in Unreal Engine 5.6 thanks to a main
conceptual change for biomes. A new
local biome core PCG component in graph
produces point data per biome actor. So
everything is defined and generated
locally. The per biome points are then
used in the global biome core which only
updates and spawns modified point data
improving workflow performance. With the
updated biome sample, you can take a
deeper look at how to leverage the new
GPU functionalities, including the
runtime GPU ground scatter example. This
example leverages the PCG GPU landscape
runtime virtual texture interface and
micro scattering providing in editor
resources as you develop your own
projects. As you are working on your own
projects, you now have an improved
debugging workflow. Open up a PCG graph
to take a look within the debug window.
The debug object tree view will
dynamically populate with filtering.
Unreal Engine 5.6 also has better error
and warning display, improving your
debug process. In general, Unreal Engine
5.6 advancements are geared towards
improving your entire world building
process with the updated procedural
tools. To see more details about the
improved performance and usability,
check out the Unreal Engine 5.6 release
notes, which go into greater detail on
GPU data, execution efficiency, and
more. Now, let's take a look at Unreal
Engine 5.7's latest updates of features
as PCG becomes production ready. With
Unreal Engine 5.7, performance and
customization continues to improve.
Let's dive in. First off, we have the
PCG editor mode located in the drop-down
button menu at the top of the viewport.
This offers a library of customizable
tools built on the PCG framework,
including the ability to draw a spline,
paint points, or create a volume. Each
tool is linked to a PCG graph, enabling
creators to have real-time parameter
control and the ability to create new
tools with no coding necessary, making
world building easier than before.
Within the PCG graph, there's now a new
polygon 2D data type, which takes input
point or spline data and turns them into
polygon 2D. Following that you have
create surface from polygon 2D offset
polygon and polygon operations allowing
you to further curate your defined
closed shapes for spline data itself.
There are two new operators called the
spline intersection and split splines
that provide additional ways for you to
work with your data. These extensions
increase the flexibility of the
procedural content you can build with
PCG, laying the groundwork to
efficiently build splinebased elements
in your scene. Want to extend the
framework further? You now have access
to custom data types in Unreal Engine
5.7, making it easier to create
proprietary tool sets. Built on the
procedural content generation framework
in Unreal Engine 5.7 is the new
experimental procedural vegetation
editor, otherwise known as PVE.
This enables you to create and edit
highquality, highly performant nanite
ready quicksix megaplant assets in real
time which are currently available on
Fab. To utilize this, enable PVE by
going to edit plugins and searching for
procedural vegetation. PVE directly
outputs nanite skeletal assemblies
supporting the latest nanite foliage
advancements such as voxilation,
bonedriven wind animation, and instance
assemblies. To take advantage of nanite
foliage capabilities, enable the
experimental nanite foliage in the
project settings. Stay tuned for more
updates on PVE and Quickixel Mega Plans.
Now, this wraps up some of the
procedural content generation
advancements in Unreal Engine 5.7. Both
Unreal Engine 5.6 and 5.7 bring
substantial improvements to your PCG
workflow with the goal of making creator
workflows for building large worlds more
powerful and efficient. With that, we
wish you a happy and easier world
